lines.text: Enter KENT and OSWALD, severally

lines.speaker: oswald
lines.text: Good dawning to thee, friend: art of this house

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: Ay.

lines.speaker: oswald
lines.text: Where may we set our horses

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: I the mire.

lines.speaker: oswald
lines.text: Prithee, if thou lovest me, tell me.

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: I love thee not.

lines.speaker: oswald
lines.text: Why, then, I care not for thee.

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: If I had thee in Lipsbury pinfold, I would make thee care for me.

lines.speaker: oswald
lines.text: Why dost thou use me thus I know thee not.

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: Fellow, I know thee.

lines.speaker: oswald
lines.text: What dost thou know me for

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: A knave a rascal an eater of broken meats a base, proud, shallow, beggarly, threesuited, hundredpound, filthy, worstedstocking knave a lilylivered, actiontaking knave, a whoreson, glassgazing, superserviceable finical rogue onetrunkinheriting slave one that wouldst be a bawd, in way of good service, and art nothing but the composition of a knave, beggar, coward, pandar, and the son and heir of a mongrel bitch: one whom I will beat into clamorous whining, if thou deniest the least syllable of thy addition.

lines.speaker: oswald
lines.text: Why, what a monstrous fellow art thou, thus to rail on one that is neither known of thee nor knows thee!

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: What a brazenfaced varlet art thou, to deny thou knowest me! Is it two days ago since I tripped up thy heels, and beat thee before the king Draw, you rogue: for, though it be night, yet the moon shines Ill make a sop o the moonshine of you: draw, you whoreson cullionly barbermonger, draw.
Drawing his sword

lines.speaker: oswald
lines.text: Away! I have nothing to do with thee.

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: Draw, you rascal: you come with letters against the king and take vanity the puppets part against the royalty of her father: draw, you rogue, or Ill so carbonado your shanks: draw, you rascal come your ways.

lines.speaker: oswald
lines.text: Help, ho! murder! help!

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: Strike, you slave stand, rogue, stand you neat slave, strike.
Beating him

lines.speaker: oswald
lines.text: Help, ho! murder! murder!
Enter EDMUND, with his rapier drawn, CORNWALL, REGAN, GLOUCESTER, and Servants

lines.speaker: edmund
lines.text: How now! Whats the matter

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: With you, goodman boy, an you please: come, Ill flesh ye come on, young master.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Weapons! arms! What s the matter here

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Keep peace, upon your lives: He dies that strikes again. What is the matter

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: The messengers from our sister and the king.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: What is your difference speak.

lines.speaker: oswald
lines.text: I am scarce in breath, my lord.

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: No marvel, you have so bestirred your valour. You cowardly rascal, nature disclaims in thee: a tailor made thee.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Thou art a strange fellow: a tailor make a man

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: Ay, a tailor, sir: a stonecutter or painter could not have made him so ill, though he had been but two hours at the trade.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Speak yet, how grew your quarrel

lines.speaker: oswald
lines.text: This ancient ruffian, sir, whose life I have spared at suit of his gray beard,

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: Thou whoreson zed! thou unnecessary letter! My lord, if you will give me leave, I will tread this unbolted villain into mortar, and daub the wall of a jakes with him. Spare my gray beard, you wagtail

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Peace, sirrah! You beastly knave, know you no reverence

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: Yes, sir but anger hath a privilege.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Why art thou angry

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: That such a slave as this should wear a sword, Who wears no honesty. Such smiling rogues as these, Like rats, oft bite the holy cords atwain Which are too intrinse t unloose smooth every passion That in the natures of their lords rebel Bring oil to fire, snow to their colder moods Renege, affirm, and turn their halcyon beaks With every gale and vary of their masters, Knowing nought, like dogs, but following. A plague upon your epileptic visage! Smile you my speeches, as I were a fool Goose, if I had you upon Sarum plain, Ild drive ye cackling home to Camelot.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Why, art thou mad, old fellow

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: How fell you out say that.

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: No contraries hold more antipathy Than I and such a knave.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Why dost thou call him a knave  Whats his offence

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: His countenance likes me not.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: No more, perchance, does mine, nor his, nor hers.

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: Sir, tis my occupation to be plain: I have seen better faces in my time Than stands on any shoulder that I see Before me at this instant.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: This is some fellow, Who, having been praised for bluntness, doth affect A saucy roughness, and constrains the garb Quite from his nature: he cannot flatter, he, An honest mind and plain, he must speak truth! An they will take it, so if not, hes plain. These kind of knaves I know, which in this plainness Harbour more craft and more corrupter ends Than twenty silly ducking observants That stretch their duties nicely.

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: Sir, in good sooth, in sincere verity, Under the allowance of your great aspect, Whose influence, like the wreath of radiant fire On flickering Phoebus front,

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: What meanst by this

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: To go out of my dialect, which you discommend so much. I know, sir, I am no flatterer: he that beguiled you in a plain accent was a plain knave which for my part I will not be, though I should win your displeasure to entreat me to t.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: What was the offence you gave him

lines.speaker: oswald
lines.text: I never gave him any: It pleased the king his master very late To strike at me, upon his misconstruction When he, conjunct and flattering his displeasure, Trippd me behind being down, insulted, raild, And put upon him such a deal of man, That worthied him, got praises of the king For him attempting who was selfsubdued And, in the fleshment of this dread exploit, Drew on me here again.

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: None of these rogues and cowards But Ajax is their fool.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Fetch forth the stocks! You stubborn ancient knave, you reverend braggart, Well teach you

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: Sir, I am too old to learn: Call not your stocks for me: I serve the king On whose employment I was sent to you: You shall do small respect, show too bold malice Against the grace and person of my master, Stocking his messenger.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Fetch forth the stocks! As I have life and honour, There shall he sit till noon.

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: Till noon! till night, my lord and all night too.

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: Why, madam, if I were your fathers dog, You should not use me so.

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: Sir, being his knave, I will.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: This is a fellow of the selfsame colour Our sister speaks of. Come, bring away the stocks!
Stocks brought out

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Let me beseech your grace not to do so: His fault is much, and the good king his master Will cheque him for t: your purposed low correction Is such as basest and contemnedst wretches For pilferings and most common trespasses Are punishd with: the king must take it ill, That hes so slightly valued in his messenger, Should have him thus restraind.

lines.speaker: cornwall
lines.text: Ill answer that.

lines.speaker: regan
lines.text: My sister may receive it much more worse, To have her gentleman abused, assaulted, For following her affairs. Put in his legs. Come, my good lord, away.
KENT is put in the stocks
Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER and KENT

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: I am sorry for thee, friend tis the dukes pleasure, Whose disposition, all the world well knows, Will not be rubbd nor stoppd: Ill entreat for thee.

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: Pray, do not, sir: I have watched and travelld hard Some time I shall sleep out, the rest Ill whistle. A good mans fortune may grow out at heels: Give you good morrow!

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: The dukes to blame in this twill be ill taken.
Exit

lines.speaker: kent
lines.text: Good king, that must approve the common saw, Thou out of heavens benediction comest To the warm sun! Approach, thou beacon to this under globe, That by thy comfortable beams I may Peruse this letter! Nothing almost sees miracles But misery: I know tis from Cordelia, Who hath most fortunately been informd Of my obscured course and shall find time From this enormous state, seeking to give Losses their remedies. All weary and oerwatchd, Take vantage, heavy eyes, not to behold This shameful lodging. Fortune, good night: smile once more: turn thy wheel!
Sleeps
